Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I feel like I learned a lot about the political events that have led to our current political atmosphere.
Critical analysis of first and second hand sources, looking at issues through a historical lens, seeing patterns over longer trajectories rather than only current trends, popular culture analysis.
How our country has changed and how it is still the same

This class focused on the moments, people and major themes throughout history that shape the United States we live in now. I learned a lot about certain aspects of contemporary history I hadn't previously covered in other history courses (9/11, the Obama presidency, the Reagan Revolution...) as well as how to consider my own historicity and orientation within them. I really liked that writing assignments in this class were more about the legacies of this history as opposed to the facts and figures themselves, because we could truly focus on applying historical lessons to present day themes. I learned how to think about the context of today's world and the links, both indirect and direct, between early 20th century history and contemporary social, political, and economic issues.

I learned so much about American history and how it has all come together to create the current moment. You really get to see the trends that go through history that start to explain how things are today.

I learned so much taking this course. It covers such a wide range of topics that are all extremely relevant. Combines an excellent overview of 20th century history with a historical application of how issues are still relevant in the present. Addresses cultural aspects of social change that often go unaddressed or left out, especially in political science courses.

I learned how to analyze historically and contextualize EVERYTHING. It is amazing. This class changed my life. I'll read op-eds, hear comments from people, or see a Billboard and I'm analyzing it in my head for historical trends.
I learned a lot about economics and the late 80s, which was useful. I also learned a bunch of stuff that I then followed up about after class.
I learned a lot about historical thinking and gained the ability to think about current events and myself as products of history, personal and wide-reaching.
I learned so much about the way society works - it has opened my eyes to so much crap that goes on in society that dates so far back in history.

This class teaches you the events of the past 100 years and some of the political and cultural events that have shaped how we see the world today. I learned so much about how to look at my own life like a historian, and how to think critically about the history we already know.
liberal perspective on modern history
I learned to historicize the world around me.

This course filled some important gaps in my knowledge of recent American history -- especially related to the Vietnam war, deindustrialization, and neoliberalism. The structure of the course was also so interesting -- it was designed to encourage us to historicize everything in the present, and I think it was really helpful.

"The starting point of critical elaboration is the consciousness of what one really is, and is 'knowing thyself' as a product of the historical process to date, which has deposited in you an infinity of traces, without leaving an inventory." - Antonio Gramsci

This course provided a comprehemsive overview of how historical precedents have brought us to the current moment. As an American citizen, it provided me with knowledge, skills, and insights Ill carry with me going forward.
I learned to historicize the cultural artifacts that surround us daily!
How to contextualize history and and the historicity of current events
I learned how to contextualize today's politics and events using history from the 20th century.

This class had a strong survey of United States history, in the context of often forgotten pieces of history in this country. It was especially interesting in its lineage, insofar as the professor takes the class from the present to the past rather than from the past to the presence. It was an insightful learning experience and the books and course content was well selected.
Learned how to critically view current events
I gained so much insight and knowledge about a period in American history that I had really never studied in depth before.
To think critically about how the past has led to the present and to take on new and unique perspectives on the world around us.
I learned how to consider myself in the midst of a "historical moment," and analyze the ways the events around me interact with former historical events and events to come.

We learnt various events and themes in US History that have particular historical relevance to the present. In general, this covered the last century of US history. We learnt to think historically about how historical forces act, understood the idea of culture being politically influential, and the ways in which the past can be excavated from the present.
I developed the skills necessary to historicize the present day and my own personal life.
I learned a significant amount about the concept of "historicity," learned about ways to really analyze the present using history, and learned how to better historicize my every day experience.
A introductory look at many major events in American history and democracy.
I learned how to historize the present moment and understand my personal history and historical viewpoint.
so much information about American history
a brief overview of American history and how is it still relevant in today's society
I deep understanding of our historical moment. Appreciated the connections across time periods with special attention to race.

I finally kind of know what neoliberalism means. Now, when my friends get drunk and lay around a room lackadaisically speaking of gentrification and the privatization of their hometowns, I have the vocabulary words to place their anecdotal experience within large movements in American history. 

I'm not sure if Professor Jacobson taught me anything substantive about American history. Most of what he covers are events that were taught to you in high school AP classes; the Reagan administration, the AIDS crisis, civil rights movements, the Great Depression, etc., but he presents them through a different lens. He's trying to teach students to see the system behind singular events. It's a different mode of thinking, the kind of liberal arts education Yale brags about on its brochures. I enjoyed lectures and sections.

This course taught 20th century American history, including the later parts that are skimmed over in many broader U.S. history courses, with a particular focus on understanding how each major period built toward our current political moment. It helped me learn how to identify the links in substance and tactics between social and political movements, and how to see an event both for its significance at the time and its historical significance in retrospect. It also taught me how to look carefully at cultural pieces as historical artifacts, understanding which broke new ground and how they reflect undercurrents not always visible in political history.
Really cool way to think about history because most classes dont look at history from a cultural perspective (as opposed to military, politics, economics, etc)

The greatest takeaway I got from the course was Professor Jacobson's insistence on historicizing everything and view cultural productions as historically produced texts worth considering and understanding.
I learned how to view cultural artifacts and current events through a historical lens. I took niche information and showed how it related to larger global trends.
Above all, I developed a greater understanding of the ways in which historical moments can be understood by contextualizing them in relation to larger themes and other moments.

Learning about historicizing the events that happen today. Things we covered (not everything listed): neoliberalism, post-Obama, post 9/11, civil rights era, stonewall & women's rights, deindustrialization, post-industrial society, etc. A cool class to think about the things that we overlook in our every day lives, but not EXACTLY the class that you will talk about current events in. Think about this as more of a class where you are learning about the history of some early, mostly late and mid 1900s that led up to today

I learned a lot about the techniques and modes of analysis of cultural history  this class was really a cultural history of the 20th-21st centuries, and it taught me a lot of new perspectives and narratives about things that I knew/thought I knew. The main thing I learned was how to historicize things going on right now and especially how to analyze and critique cultural objects: things like tv shows, movies, advertisements, products  to see the political work that they do.

By taking this course, I learned a lot about the historical trends that explain why the nation is what it is today. I also learned a lot about how to analyze the history behind photos and quotations. The main insight that you gain from this course is that history is everywhere and defines almost everything.
I honed the ability to understand the history of our current political climate as well as everyday events such as the tv shows I watch.

This course gave me a better understanding of American history from now back to the time of the Great Depression. I learned, in great depth, about movements like neoliberalism and the Stonewall Riots and how these movements have shaped modern day America.

how to think about the present through the historical context that shaped it. We learned to look at who we are and what our moment has become through the most recent history that created it. Learned to think critically about how different events work together through time periods and how events in the same time period work together and were shaped by previous time periods.

This course is a solid trip through history. I did not have strong history instruction in high school, and so this class operated as a good overview of some of the major events and players from the 20th and 21st centuries. Focusing on specific movements and periods, the course also highlights cultural trends that proceeded and followed the specified dates. Overall, this class is a great introduction to recent American history, although it does skip over a lot due to time constraints.
In general, this course focused on historical movements and processes in the past 50 years that shaped the current state of our country.
How to think about the world better and better understand the present moment
I learned everything that could possible explain our current political and social climate.

Due to the nature of this course, I did not walk away with a complete picture of contemporary US history. What the class does do is analyze themes in US history and ties them back into present day (though it would have been more interesting if it related more to the present). There is a conscious effort to avoid talking about Trump's politics... but I was really hoping we would dive farther into what created the present dysfunction in government. The class handles particularly well post 9/11, post-second wave feminism, and post-deindustrialization.

I learned about various social and political movements and ideologies that emerged in recent history that created the foundation for our current moment, including the Civil Rights Movement, neoliberalism, deindustrialization, the gay rights movement, the 1965 Hart-Cellar Immigration Act, and the New Deal, among many others. I also gained insight into the importance of cultural and cultural productions in doing political work, or the "work that culture does," and gained more knowledge and language to think more critically about the pop culture and media that we currently consume, what it means for marginalized communities, in particular communities of color, and how my own historicity provides a lens through which I view and interpret things.

I learned about how we all carry a kind of historicity with us and how history impacts and plays a role in our lives today. The political, economic, and social atmosphere of today is a product of history and it is important to understand the historical context behind current events in order to move forward and affect change.
Looking at present history more analytically and thoughtfully.
Lectures are very interesting. Discussion sections are informative, but not very relevant.
Lectures are very engaging and in many respects eye opening. Only issue is perhaps that there is too little time to fully cover all areas touched upon.

Weakness - made you BUY a book every week and read 300+ pages. It was ridiculous how much reading there was when it was not even necessary for the tests. The teacher also was extremely politically skewed and projected his political beliefs into his teaching. He also taught in a disorganized way.

This course was incredibly engaging and relevant  it feels like not a week went by that at least one aspect of my everyday life reminded me of something we had covered in lecture (from tv episodes to news items to campus events). Lectures were always entertaining and informative, especially because of Professor Jacobson's incorporation of multimedia clips and unique frameworks through which to view history that many of us had already covered before in some form. I think the lectures and readings were a highlight of the course experience, and everything tied together very nicely. The workload was manageable and the exams were fair, even if they felt hard to prepare for beyond doing the readings and going to lecture. The readings were for the most part really interesting and refreshing in that they were not dryly covering the same tired subjects most American history majors have already studied (I especially liked the Traister, Coates, Dunbar-Ortiz, Mayer, and Bayoumi readings). Sections were also great, because there was always so much to talk about and I learned a lot from my classmates and TA, Megann (who is fabulous  consistently prepared, very responsive and fair, and really smart without coming across as pretentious). I really adored this class, and my only suggestion for improvement would be to broaden the ideological perspective a bit  it felt at times very much like an echo chamber, because Prof. Jacobson is obviously liberal as is the majority (if not entirely) of the class, and I think we all agreed with his take on most topics, but I personally would have liked him to incorporate (either each week or as a wrap up towards the end of the semester) a kind of "History of Right Now for people who disagree with us" and an application of these lessons to conservative perspectives. For example, how do conservatives view the Reagan Revolution and the New Deal? How could we apply what we covered in the Post-Second Wave unit in conversations with people who disavow feminism? I think part of why I loved this class so much was that it gave me new perspectives and evidence to back up many of my political beliefs, but it was always clear they were coming from someone with this particular point of view intended for a liberal leaning audience, and I would love to know how to translate these lessons into people from across the political spectrum in today's polarized world (especially where there is an increasing sense of history/liberal arts not mattering, which this class really disproves).

The structure of the course is amazing. Professor Jacobson does two-part lessons going from most recent to further in the past. The readings are interesting but can be long and it would be better if we were given excerpts to focus on instead of whole books each week. The lectures were always interesting and there was so much to learn and take in, even if it's history you already knew about.

The course lecture is amazing. Section is required but it did not feel totally necessary. The course has two short papers and a final exam but I think replacing the final exam with a longer final paper would better demonstrate knowledge of the course and allow students to explore in depth one of the topics we talked about.
Professor Jacobson is a fantastic professor and does an incredible job of providing a new lens to topics that some have and some have not learned about before.

Strengths: Prof Jacobson is the best professor I've had at Yale. The books are really interesting and complementary, but the lectures themselves are amazing. While having both papers and exams objectively kind of sucks, the papers are really fun to do and the exams really let you play up the aspects of the course that you were most engaged in.

Weaknesses: I'm really at a loss to think of weaknesses; this is the best class I have ever taken. Section I guess could be slow sometimes, but that's section everywhere.
Having tests feels really strange, especially with the papers -- I would rather have a narrower paper prompt and no tests.

This course does an excellent job of teaching students how to think historically and consider the world around them as a product of history. The greatest weakness of this course was the reading- it was far too lengthy, and almost no students actually did it. If shorter readings were assigned, students would have been able to complete them rather than opting not to purchase books that they wouldn't have had time to read and doing no reading at all.

The lectures were fantastic, the information was really interesting, the reading load was just a little too heavy, so I think people ended up not reading parts that were actually important from some really good texts.

Strengths - the professor and the information. I learned an incredible amount and really loved listening to what he had to say. Weaknesses - the class felt unstructured - studying based off of his lecture slides was largely impossible because his slides would post photos of TV shows or maps and have no information about it. After the first midterm I realized that I needed to know about small details like that so I took better notes in lecture, but in the first half of the semester I didn't know. Reading a book a week was a pain- and VERY expensive. Not all the books were even available at Yale Bookstore. But despite all of this - I still really loved this class which shows how interesting and great it is!

I loved this course and thought that Jacobson's lectures were extremely engaging and insightful. While I loved all the books we read, I thought we could definitely benefit from having more time to talk about them instead of only in section, and maybe having less than one book per week.
personal political beliefs of professor often bleed into "factual" lectures

Lecture was definitely a strength. Professor Jacobson has a way of narrating events and trends that made the things I had taken for granted as normal seem completely bizarre. It was like a wake-up call. One weakness was that we really only heard a very liberal perspective on events -- while lectures were incredibly insightful, I think it would have been helpful to learn more narratives that Professor Jacobson disagreed with.

Strengths: mind-bogglingly strong lectures that inspired me to reimagine the past century of United States history in fascinating ways, mostly excellent books assigned, going back in time rather than forward, emphasis on a unique style of thinking historically, and essays that had us historicize the present.

Weaknesses: it ended.
No real weaknesses. Professor Jacobson organized the course in a great way to facilitate learning and was an engaging lecturer.
Less reading assigned - makes us more likely to do it - cut book load in half!

Strengths- exciting lectures, valuable insights from professor and peers

Weaknesses- heavy reading load

The material is very interesting, especially if you're interested in modern US history/politics. The readings are too long and could definitely be shortened to just a few assigned chapters/ pages rather than entire books. Lectures were very engaging, but they sometimes felt disorganized towards the second half of the semester because of falling behind schedule.
This course was well taught and well organized and the lectures were interesting, although it amounted to more class time than most courses (two 75 minute lectures and a 50 minute section).
Awesome Professor and very interesting material
I really enjoyed the lectures and sections. There was too much reading, I, or anyone I talked to, ever completed all of it.

Strengths are that the lectures were always engaging and that the powerpoint slides helped us visualize whatever was being discusses. Photographs, music, and video clips were an integral part of the course's success. A main weakness was that we were required to read a book per week and oftentimes this proved too difficult of an assignment.

Strengths: The lectures are just about the most interesting thing I've ever experienced. I especially loved how much cultural history came to the forefront, as the class focused primarily on how history affects, protects, harms, helps (etc) people. 

Weakness: I couldn't keep up with the weekly readings (a book a week) because it was my fifth credit.

Strengths: The course readings were enjoyable - if long - and the lectures were well-delivered with a lot of passion and preparation. Prof. Jacobson takes pride in his work and was very dedicated in planning the course.

Weaknesses: At times, the course seemed overly concerned with only historically excavating what was relevant to the present, and often exceptionalized today's "right now." It also felt a little lacking in depth in nuance, more in the nature of a survey course, which was perhaps inevitable given the size of the course. Section, meanwhile, was often a drag, and not because of any lack of effort from the TA. With a book a week, readings were inevitably incomplete and section was often reduced to talking about the news.

Strengths: Incredible professor and TF, engaging course material, exciting lectures
Weaknesses: None

I thought that Professor Jacobson was very engaging and knowledgeable, and I appreciated the ways in which he encouraged students to analyze and historicize their present. I appreciated the cultural history components, but thought that they sometimes weren't as well-integrated into lectures as they could have been. I also think that the class could have been 50 minutes rather than 75 minutes long.

The course gave a general overview of American democracy history, and was interesting in that respect. However, lectures were very predictable and never really gave further or different insight beyond what you'd expect from a cursory knowledge of the subject and the general 'liberal' point of view. The assignments were reasonable, but the reading was really a lot -- one book per week.

This course was incredible. It should be a requirement for all Yale students. Truly taught me how to cope with current events, understand the present from a larger historical viewpoint, and to find peace in these revelations.

strength was that is was really interesting and Dr. Jacobson put a really unique perspective on historical events and their legacies. 
Weakness was that is was very unorganized and had to read a book a week when really probably could have gotten away with reading just excerpts of the book

I thought the course was really well thought out, and for the most part I enjoyed the book selection. I liked the essay assignments and doing the midterm/final, I thought the final was slightly too long. I also thought that some of the graphs/data were presented with too little context, and it made me skeptical of the argument being made. Single numbers are always dangerous, so I wanted to know more information to understand the trends! Also it would have been helpful to have other interpretations/counter-points to the main lectures would have made them stronger! Overall great attention to highlighting many different voices which I appreciated.

This course has many strengths, as I've outlined in my responses to the other questions, but its focus on engaging critically with multiple perspectives on historical events has been particularly important. It does this through presenting alternate narratives in lecture, through books that take a particular point of view, and through inviting lively debate in sections. The encouragement to attend and make connections with relevant film screenings and outside lectures was also great. The only weakness is that the readings can become quite long, and since they weren't central to participating and succeeding in the course, they often seemed to be skimmed or ignored by many students.

Very interesting and necessary skills and knowledge taught in the class. There were a lot of little facts that were not necessary. For understanding but made the final and midterm unnecessarily harder.

Strengths: lectures, reading list, structure of class, content, assignments. Weaknesses: incorporating the readings into lectures and especially into section  they were great, but we didn't take enough time to talk about them.

This course needs to be more balanced. Professor Jacobson told us how this class is designed to teach us how to think but in reality this class taught us how he thinks. Every single book and lecture was very liberal. I am a liberal, a registered Democrat, and agree with most if not all of Professors views. But the fact that there was zero representation of the other side of ANY issue shows the pitfalls of our society. This class did not foster any sort of debate or conversation, and was simply Professor teaching us his views about current events and why they are correct, without acknowledging that there are other, legitimate sides to basically everything we talked about. That said, Professor Jacobson is a great lecturer and his lectures were very interesting.

The course has a lot of information which is great. The individual lectures flow very well because all of the history is intertwined within a theme of that lecture. However, the overall course does not flow well. It is extremely difficult to study for because it has a lot of overlapping information between themes.

I think the course was super strong overall. I think having a book or two less a semester would be helpful because it was clear many couldnt get to every one each week which made section discussion more difficult. Reading fewer books would also allow us to talk more about what we learned in class in section as well as attempt to assess events we dont discuss in class in a similar way to how we do in class.

Strengths: the course material is super interesting and incredibly relevant to students' participation in today's society. Prof Jacobson does a good job of teaching us about the periods that our previous history classes always skip, allowing us to think historically about the period that we are living in. Lectures are always engaging and the readings are too. 

Weaknesses: the course sometimes paints political debates as black and white (dems=good, reps=bad). Often, this conclusion comes implicitly and can lead students farther left whilst demonizing and failing to understand the logic, priorities and though processes that go into more conservative thinking. Conservatives can't always be wrong, or always be evil and democrats can't always be right or always be honest and well-intentioned. 
Further, while all the readings are relevant and interesting, they can be too much. A book a week is not realistic.

The intended course structure was very clear and thoughtful. However, often Professor Jacobson had SO much to say about each topic that it began to feel rushed at the end. In his effort to impart everything that he knows, I don't feel like I truly absorbed a lot of the material. Thus, slightly more focused topics or lectures would be a good thing if the class is taught in the future. Also, although all the books were very interesting and definitely texts I would love to read, an entire book a week for a lecture is not practical. Students will stop doing the readings if it is more than around 50 pages a week for a lecture. They won't read not because they don't want to but because we simply don't have the time with three or four other classes and everything else that we have going on. Therefore, I recommend highlighting important chapters from the books so that students feel like the reading is more manageable and will be more likely to complete it.

The primary weakness of this course was that it in large part lacked historical objectivity. Even as a liberal student, I was frustrated at times when the information presented was not a record of events, but rather a far-left commentary on events and their impact. I'm not entirely sure what I learned in the class, since the majority of what was taught was opinion and political talking points.
THIS COURSE WAS MY FAVORITE CLASS AT YALE - THANK YOU PROFESSOR JACOBSON
It was incredibly relevant to todays world and I loved every lecture.

Strengths: a dedicated professor, thought-provoking lectures, interesting subject matter.

Weaknesses: I would have preferred 50-minute lectures. Also it would have been better to keep the structure suggested at the beginning of the term where the first lecture of the week is background information and the second is a more critical analysis-- each issue veered too much to one side or the other. The reading list is entirely too long. Since it feels unmanageable, it leads students to not even attempt the reading. If selections were chosen from the books, students would be much more likely to do some of the reading. This is among the reasons that discussion section was not good. Also, my teaching assistant was new to teaching and unfortunately that meant she was more worried about us liking her than she was about pushing us to speak critically or ask tough questions. Hopefully the other sections were better, but ours was a waste of time in which we often just watched media clips.

Professor Jacobson is an incredible lecturer. I thought that the course provided a really great overview of recent history and provided students with the tools and knowledge of history to think critically about the current moment. Throughout the course, I found myself thinking more deeply about the media and pop culture that I encountered in the everyday. I also really appreciated how Professor Jacobson informed us about relevant lectures on campus and in New Haven -- I went to one of these speaker events with Jill Lepore, and as someone interested in information and data, found it extremely fascinating and meaningful! However, the course moves very quickly and tries to cover a lot of material, which can be beneficial in providing an overview of the historical trends in a given time period, but I oftentimes felt like breadth was emphasized at the expense of depth. I wish the course had more historical meat in discussing specific dates, events, and policies, and it sometimes felt like we were only getting a minute smattering of the sentiments and statistics in an era with no clear idea of what we were missing in what was _not_ being mentioned. I also felt like the workload of having to read a book the same week in which one of the two papers was due could be overwhelming and oftentimes meant that students would forgo reading the book, but would still have to purchase it for the sake of bringing it to section, in lieu of writing the paper. Additionally, though the first half of the course (prior to spring break) was relatively well organized, I thought the second half of the course was less well-organized in terms of breaking up each lecture into distinct sections or themes.

-readings were long (a book a week is a lot)
-excellent professor
-enjoyed writing the papers (got a lot of freedom to write about what we were really interested in)
-engaged current events with the class, intertwined news and our own personal experiences with what we were learning
-lectures sometimes went too fast, lecture slides mostly just had pictures so it sometimes made it hard to follow but the images/audio/video were helpful learning aids
Professor Jacobson is one of the best lecturers Ive had at Yale thus far. The other being Crystal Feimster.
Uh, if you want to learn about this topic, you should probably credit/D/fail it. It was so much work.
Absolutely, it has been one of my favourite courses ever taken. Readings assigned were interesting, lectures were engaging and section deepened understanding and challenged the thought-process.

If you want to read 300+ pages of reading every week, sure. The information was so interesting but I believe it was just taught in a poor way. It was difficult to actually engage in the material because I was so stressed about completing the readings.
Jacobson is a fantastic lecturer! Very topical lectures, approachable for non-humanities majors.

I will absolutely recommend this course to every single student at Yale, regardless of political orientation or academic/extracurricular interest. I do think people will get more out of the course if they have taken US history courses in the past, because a foundation of basic 20th century history is helpful and also highlights the ways in which this class approaches it differently in order to tie it into "right now." You will learn how to think critically and historically about the present by examining some of the most important people, events, themes, trends, and changes of the past, and you will have a ton of fun while doing so  the lectures are so enthralling, Professor Jacobson is a star in the field and really wants students to get the most out of the semester, sections are always a blast and the readings are handpicked to be relevant/manageable/interesting. It's not an overwhelming amount of work and the assessments test what you've learned while emphasizing your personal experiences and without requiring rote memorization. It would make for a good 5th class or credit/d, a fresh perspective on history for an upperclassman history major, and a great class for a senior who wants to learn something they can apply in their real world conversations, pleasure reading and news consumption.

Yes! This was the best class I've taken so far. Professor Jacobson is extremely engaging and passionate about the material. The essays are interesting to write and the readings are incredible and useful beyond the scope of the class.
Yes! Take this course!! Jacobson is incredible and this is one of the best courses I have taken at Yale.

Absolutely take this class if you can! Professor Jacobson is an incredible professor, does a really fantastic job with teaching the material, and brings a new lens to history as he incorporates many other disciplines along with it. Take this class!!
Yes yes yes! EVERYONE should take this class.

This a crash course in liberal indoctrination. While Jacobson is a talented lecturer, issues were often presented without nuance and tainted by the professor's blatant bias. Some lectures were interesting and substantive, whereas others were incredibly fluffy. Exams were creative and fun, however, and I did enjoy them.
Yeah
I would recommend this course to almosts any Yale student, as it teaches critical life skills for understanding the present.
Definitely! Take this course!!! It's so important right now, and it will change the way you understand this country and our present politics.
yes

Yes! The workload is considerable, and because this was the first year it was taught, perhaps the structure of it was lacking - but it was an amazing class that taught me so much about the way of the world and opened my eyes. It has made me want to change my major and entire career path.

I would 100% recommend this course to every student. This class was by far my favorite of the semester and taught me so much about the past century of history. You wouldn't want to miss out on learning from such an engaging professor and amazing teaching fellows.
lots of reading but good class, readings werent really essential
Yes. Incredible class, incredible professor. Take it. One of my favorite classes at Yale.
Yes! Incredible course that really changes the way I consume information, culture, news, and politics in my everyday life.
This was my favorite course I've taken at Yale so far. Absolutely!
Absolutely! Im so happy that it was one of my final classes at Yale. If offered again, I recommend to any student.
I absolutely would! The course provides insight into history that is often missed in conventional history classes.
Yes because I walked away having learned so much about how we got to this moment in America
Yes, especially if you're interested in 20th century American history and understanding the influences of modern US culture/ politics.
This course was strong and interesting that helps contextualize important parts of all of our lives.
Yes!
absolutely. this class was one of the best that I've taken so far, and professor Jacobsen was great.
Yes, although depressing, it was a very interesting course.

Absolutely - not only is Professor Jacobson a fantastic lecturer and phenomenal historian, but these topics are so relevant to where we are today and from this course, I was able to understand the historical complexities that led to the "right now."

Absolutely, this class was one of the best that I have taken at Yale and I am confident that what I have learned will stick with me through the rest of my life. Professor Jacobson is an engaging speaker and is a brilliant observer of the world that we live in. I always looked forward to going to this class.
YES! This is currently my favorite class at Yale.

I'm not sure. Somehow, I ended up somewhat underwhelmed. The course syllabus promised a lot but ultimately I felt that I didn't learn with as much depth as I'd have liked. The lectures were overviews, as was expected, but at section, for example, we spent little time actually getting deeper into historical themes. The course framed its historical moment a little too uni-dimensionally, while the "historical method" espoused didn't offer any new insights. That said, this is by no means a bad course and will only get better.
Absolutely. Best course I have taken at Yale.

YES! My absolute favorite class not only this semester but possibly at Yale overall. Each lecture is engaging relevant (as per the course title) and the majority of the information has helped me look at "breaking news" from a completely different perspective.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Professor Jacobson is clearly well-versed in the themes and moments in history that he covered in lecture, and I especially appreciated his ability to tie the present in with the past about which he was lecturing. The course taught me to think about both history and the present in a new light, which was something I really valued.

I would highly recommend this course to everyone I know. This has been by far my favorite course from both an educational and personal persepective. This course has been the most impactful course I've taken on my personal development.

I LOVED THIS CLASS. Would highly recommend- Jacobson is the kind of lecturer who you can just listen to and not take notes and retain the information because you are so engaged. I loved the content and the way he organized it. TAKE THIS CLASS.  My only regret is taking it credit/D because I ended up doing very well in it.
yes if you want a unique perspective on historical events and their legacies into society today but not worth it if you are not willing to put in the time or go to class
YES! Really helps contextualize our current moment.

If you're a history major, I'm not sure if I would take this class. Professor Jacobson doesn't teach you anything particularly new or interesting about American history, but he presents it in a different light. History of Right Now is a class with a thesis. I was into it. I would take it again.

Yes!!! This has been one of my favorite courses at Yale, and it provides a great opportunity to learn and think about the most important issues of our time, particularly for anyone who hasn't yet taken a course on late 20th-century American history. The course got me to think in new ways about the relationship between culture and politics, and how collective memory distorts the complexities of the past (and even the present). Lectures were great, readings were interesting and often offered a particular focus or perspective different from the one presented in lecture, and sections prompted excellent discussions. Overall, exactly what I'd look for in a Yale course for engaging critically with the history and present of this country!
Awesome lectures, the homework isnt necessary for understanding the course and can be very time consuming. Overall great experience

I thoroughly enjoyed taking this course. While I didn't learn a whole lot of new information, it was still interesting to consider histories that I had already learned in an extremely current context. The lectures were enjoyable, engaging, and entertaining, the workload was not too extreme, and I really enjoyed my section.
Absolutely would recommend. One of my favorite classes and it totally changed my perspective on history and the world.
I would recommend this class to other students, regardless of their major or career interests.

Yeah, it's pretty interesting. That being said, if you can't take the class, maybe read a few of the books for pleasure. A good class for practice in historicizing today and thinking about your surroundings in a different way.

I really liked this class. I'd call it "Cultural History of the 20th21st Centuries" because that's really what it is: you go reverse chronologically from the present to the New Deal, mostly from the perspective of cultural history. Professor Jacobson is really great  he's extremely insightful and always manages to surprise you or make you think about something in new ways. I'm not sure how many people did the reading, but as someone who did, the books were mostly really good and fascinating; the syllabus is great. I think it's one of those classes that will stick with you in a lot of small ways.

If you have any opinion that is even remotely conservative, youre going to hate this class. There is a book a week, which is a ton of reading, and they are all very left-wing. No representation of any opinion that Professor Jacobson does not hold. The tests are easy if you study, but this class does go through an absurd amount of material, so be prepared to memorize a lot. The lectures are interesting and very practical to our everyday society, so you wont want to miss those. Essays are graded tough but interesting topics. Overall, I really enjoyed this course, and would recommend it. That said, it is very one-sided and liberal and void of any debate, so if thats your style, its the class for you.

I would recommend this course to a student who wants a good overview of large concepts in US political culture. The class teaches a lot of big trends but covers a lot of information within those trends. The class is also a lot of work if you do the readings.
Yes!!! Professor Jacobson is fantastic and this course is essential to critically thinking about the present and future.
Yes, I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The subject matter is very relevant to today and the lectures are thought-provoking.
Yes. Prof. Jacobson does an AMAZING job, the readings are incredibly interesting (and are often readings that students would like to read in their inexistent free time).
I would recommend this class. I think that it is a great overview of recent American history and relevant to everyone. The additional events are also a nice complement.
Although I can't say I learned a lot, this was one of the more enjoyable courses for me. With all the auditors in the course, it was an interesting and unique experience.
YES. Favorite class at Yale by far learned so much about both just straight facts and also how to approach life.
Yes, Jacobson is a godsend and his class was incredibly interesting everyday. I constantly think about his lessons and how they apply to regular daily life.

Perhaps. I is a fun and e class but definitely an overview-- probably not for a history major already specializing in the field. The workload is very manageable-- two tests and two short papers-- if you decide to not keep up with the hefty reading list (that you are not really held accountable for in any way).

Yes, I would recommend this class to anyone who is trying to better understand the context and history that has produced the current political and cultural moment that we are in. I would also recommend it to students who are trying to further their understanding of recent American history and think more deeply about their own historicity. it does help having taken another AMST or ER&M class before this one, as I do not necessarily think that this is a particularly introductory class.
Yes!
Yes! I loved this course. It was a unique way of looking at history through the present and provided an important historical lens to understanding current events. Professor Jacobson is also amazing!
Absolutely, especially students who are not typically humanity/social science/history people. This is a great course and an important one.
